sub_topic: Calculation of the Bohr radius in hydrogen atom
message_1: What is the Bohr radius of a hydrogen atom when its electron is in the n=1 state? Show your calculation and express the answer in meters.
message_2:
The Bohr radius of a hydrogen atom is given by the formula:

a₀ = (4πε₀ħ²) / (m_e * e²)

where:
a₀ is the Bohr radius
ε₀ is the vacuum permittivity (8.854 x 10^(-12) C²/Nm²)
ħ is the reduced Planck constant (1.055 x 10^(-34) Js)
m_e is the mass of the electron (9.109 x 10^(-31) kg)
e is the elementary charge (1.602 x 10^(-19) C)

For the n=1 state, the Bohr radius is simply a₀:

a₀ = (4π * 8.854 x 10^(-12) * (1.055 x 10^(-34))^2) / (9.109 x 10^(-31) * (1.602 x 10^(-19))^2)

a₀ ≈ 5.291 x 10^(-11) meters

So, the Bohr radius of a hydrogen atom when its electron is in the n=1 state is approximately 5.291 x 10^(-11) meters.
